JuHzxGQgXJSxH8XuMhyGCw.text: Great gastropub! We went for Sunday roast, and everyone thought it a lovely dining experience. The atmosphere of the pub and the restaurant is very nice, the staff are friendly and professional and the food was fantastic. We all had the rotisserie lamb, which I would highly recommend. It came with all the trimmings, and there was lots of it. Afterwards we had the cheeseboard, which was also very nice - the chutney was amazing.The only drawback is the noise level, I didn't mind, but my older aunties found it difficult to follow the conversation, so that is something to keep in mind if your hearing isn't great.

_2vpHBy_8vFJJzFBl6PZWQ.text: The Jugged Hare was fabulous last year but has gone properly downhill now and is comparable to a posh Harvester.  We found the "carvery"  options to be truly dull, bog-standard fare that you could find in any pub in London for half the price.  We were quite surprised that despite their efforts at being "meaty" by hanging game in the window and having a see-through meat locker, they would not prepare a burger medium rare.  Pathetically they blamed this on Westminister Council (untruth - see the Council web site).  It's completely to do with a lack of confidence in their own preparation methods, which rather makes you question whether you want to eat here at all.   We also found the service to be altogether too casual - the wait staff don't seem to take any personal responsibility for tables and you are left trying to flag someone down as they whiz past.  Truly disappointing and overpriced for what they are giving their customers.

ycQmTBbrWgZUQcO3GS1yaw.text: I will start by saying this place is probably pushing it at 4* for me but it is a solid 3.5 so to give it 3 is a little unfair. My blood sausage with fennel and apple salad starter was nice but the tiny bit of salad didn't really balance with the aize of the sausage. Also in all honesty it could've done with some bread or toast to go with it but thats a minor gripe. A big problem for me was the grouse main, it hadn't been cleaned out properly so some of the meat was slightly tainted with a very bitter taste. The restaurant was very noisy as well, I appreciate it was Sunday lunchtime but it was so noisy I couldn't hear the waitress telling me the specials from 2 feet away and had to go and read the board at the other end of the room. The sides, dessert and service however were very good. I think I would like to go back and try another dish as I get the impression I might just have been unlucky, however at £150 for Sunday lunch for 2 you would expect that not to happen. The Jugged Hare has ambitions towards fine dining and certainly some of the prices are already Michelin level. Chateau Briand with no sides included at £55 anyone? However I dont think they are quite there, it lacks the finesse of fine dining. The waitress was efficient but the folding of our napkins whenever we put them down and the topping up of water and wine felt forced here and out of place.

photos.caption: Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom

p_WvHiY8DASiChNTkY0_uQ.text: Lovely gastro pub and restaurant. Had the Sunday roast chicken and it was delicious. Great flavour and came with all the trimmings. Staff were friendly and service was quick despite the restaurant being busy. Had the sticky toffee pudding for desert and it was divine! Would recommend!

NdtK_1keW-B2EEQxZoKkOw.text: There are times when some crazy thing happens that could totally ruin a restaurant experience, things so random and unpredictable that everyone is left dumbfounded. Unfortunately, this happened when I stopped in for a quick dinner with my friend at Jugged Hare before we attended an event at The Brewery. Imagine then, if you will, a small bowl of ketchup creating a spectacular demonstration of anti-gravity and chaos theory, said bowl hit the ground and all ketchup within went splattering all over my friend, and a bit on to me. This could, quite easily, ruin a night. Thankfully, the servers and manager were extremely polite about it, brought me club soda to clean everything (old wives' tale that works!), and gave my friend the address where to send his dry-cleaning bill.And just think, that's all independent of the food and atmosphere!- they have a great selection of local beers, which always scores well with me- the fish that my friend had was very tasty, and we shared the bread- the atmosphere is perfect gastropub, reminiscent of a hunting hall, but still high end and City-qualityTwo great things: the basics were covered, and they reacted to crisis well.

4y6e5zQb-Qgb9MW6iUqgBA.text: This has to be a contender for the best Sunday roast in London! Have been a few times now and the food is always consistently good whilst the service can be hit and miss when it is really busy, though they seem to have sorted that out now. Top tip is to try the game specials they have on!

photos.caption: Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. Roast white Teal, braised lentils, heritage carrots and wild mushrooms (from the specials board)

y_XiOSr0woABoBH3lAMemg.text: Great hotel and good onsite pub/restaurant.  Have tried the pub more than once and it doesn't disappoint.  Only hesitation is the price, but service is excellent!

RIVfYqRZbYKz_jIfzMH6VQ.text: Exotic and interesting place to go.  It was a wild choice for my casual business lunch.  You can try some exotic meats here if u like trying new food. Good proportion,  good services. Decoration is very different too compared to other Restaurant in Moorgate area. They have a Bar areas too, so it is good for different occassions.  I have it four stars as the plating can be more imaginative.

RmHCWhJkV_CfuegzMRDBdQ.text: The Jugged Hare is a superior Sunday lunch - go here if you want to take your roast to the next level!Kev L. recommended we try this place out since he'd heard good things, well I am here to tell you those good things are true. This is no grimy tavern lunch, this is posh pub dining from the waiters wearing waistcoats to the wine cellar. From the second we walked in the door, eyes drawn skyward to the series of dead hare heads mounted on the walls - they were on it, delivering first class service. 'Can I offer you an aperitif before you sit down? How about a Bloody Mary?' Our own waiter was very knowledgeable and charming; explaining the heritage of each dish, offering suggestions and even advising on coffee locations afterwards. The place seems inspired by traditional English heritage with dishes on the menu that are based on recipes from centuries past  but modernised. It's very polished and stylish inside, you aren't sitting in the front bar but a full restaurant with the occasional hare motif dotted around. And the food: money well spent. Pork crackling to start and superior cuts of meat for the roasts - surrounded by a big Yorkshire pud, separate plates of veggies and creamy cauliflower cheese. The meat was served a bit rare for my liking, but i imagine it would have pleased most everyone else. We finished with a generous cheeseboard. Honestly, I cannot give you one good reason why you should eat your Sunday lunch anywhere but here. I couldn't fault their service, presentation or the quality of the food.  If you have someone to impress, parents to take out or you'd just love a decadent Sunday lunch. Go here!

Jnu6jNUvIe-NpXcoNmv10g.text: From the once desolate lands of the Barbican, comes The Jugged Hare; a much-needed watering hole for locals, tourists and commuters alike.  Created as part of Ed and Tom Martin's gastropub empire and opened in 2011, the newly renovated pub has a hunting-club-in-the-middle-of-London feel about it, with rich, dark wood panelling, sumptuous sofas and walls populated with a large collection of taxidermy.  Antique whisky barrels serve as tables while the bar serves pints of real ale and specially selected boutique wines to complement the menu.Priding itself on serving seasonal British gourmet grub, The Jugged Hare's menu serves everything from hearty offal and game to delicate shellfish and soups.  Separated into four different sections; rotisserie, grill, pot roasts and billingsgate, the main dish decision often comes down to a round of ip-dip-doo.  If the taxidermy doesn't do it, the meat-centric menu will give vegetarians The Jugged Hare's message in a jiffy; meat conquers all!  The food is delicious but does come at a price.  With wild boar and venison sausages, crisp bone marrow and shallots, jugged hare pie and other traditional British delicacies, it sometimes feels like the eyes of your victims are watching from the walls, as you tuck in with fervour.

8t_tEn8dMq-vUVkfwSQGaw.text: I cannot wait to head back. Great city location for a quick meal. Fabulous fish from Billingsgate Market.

WgT0-BAQzPQkdIY25vOWOw.text: I like this place more for the range of beer they have vs. the dead animals they use as decoration. To be fair, the bf was instagramming photos of said dead animals while I was ordering our drinks so it's not lost on everyone!The menu was written on a chalkboard and was heavily meat focused, which goes very well with the decor. Every dish had explanations except the one meatless dish that was just up there as 'vegetarian'. Not gonna lie, I may be intrigued enough to go back to try it.

-A4_cK964FaU_iUaKXKqnA.text: I enjoyed Christmas Eve dinner with friends and family at the Jugged Hare.To prevent food envy, we decided it best to share not only the starters but also our exquisite mains. To start, the salmon, horseradish, and beet root was a tasteful explosion that propelled our senses into euphoria. Entrees consisted of rump of deer, monkfish, and the signature Jugged Hare. Somehow we relinquished (a small) sharing portion of our own dishes around the table in the spirit of Christmas--everyone was very much pleased.Nice location in the City; worth it for a night after work with colleagues or a weekend gathering of friends.

z-CDizDS_k4gbmkyZk4r_Q.text: I was soooo looking forward to going to this place, but unfortunately - the hype was there, the amazing menu was there - but the rabbit didn't quite hit the spot.My friend had their version of bangers and mash - and it was good, but not amazing.I liked the atmosphere though and maybe I would give this place another chance - to check out some other exciting things from their menu but for the time being it will have to be only 3 stars.They have a cool area downstairs available for hire - it looks good - sort of wine cellar feel to it - so if you're looking for a place to hire out for a corporate (or any other event) - it maybe worth checking out.

YjDv2F3dhqynHnetL5rJBA.text: If you head to the Jugged Hare, you have to order something off the rotisserie. My personal favourite is the 1/2 chicken. The chickens are cooked perfectly and remain juicy and flavourful. Make sure to order loads of sides too. The cauliflower mac and cheese, although not guilt-free, is delicious. And you can always balance it out with almond butter broccoli. The wine list boasts great bottles at reasonable prices. The atmosphere is similar to a brasserie - loud and bustling with a full view of the kitchen. The waiters are friendly, timely and well mannered. It's the perfect place for a slightly indulgent lunch.

sMYzYBxQL02jKUazpIW5Yg.text: Good food and excellent variety, albeit fully priced. However, the room lacks any soft surfaces and as a result of that and the open kitchen is horrendously noisy. It is impossible to hear what table companions are saying so unsuited to client lunches.

CYh5vLtHTv4o222hEh9tJQ.text: Really nice City pub. Beautiful food in the dining room but also just great for some beers!

xI6oQ7Rb1wlPFE7U9os6Yg.text: Amazing pub for Sunday roast! Really outstanding!  However located in a very quite street and it's not easy to get to, you wouldn't just walk past. Go and check it out though, will not disappoint.

5D6tJ6EupRCMvYOFQSOi3Q.text: The indignation with which the staff arrogantly went about their menial jobs was so far beyond unprofessional that no single word can accurately describe it, so I will invent one. Putrivesiant. The staff were putrivesant. The slowest, rudest and most incompetent pub staff ever encountered. I recommend going just to experience it.

e_OFwplhxdVFH6-DGlHmSw.text: I love the gastropub concept so my friend and I thought we'd knock off another one on the list of Top 50 Gastropub Awards. This pub is so conveniently located in the City, I would never have thought that it had some serious food cred as well! I booked a table for 12:15 and when we arrived, we went to the back dining room where it was completely empty. It is quite a big venue, and in the back you feel like you are dining at a quite high end restaurant, so unfortunately it has lost the authentic gastropub feel. (By way of comparison, at Bull & Last we dined on the first floor right near the bar and there were no more than 10 other tables on that floor.) The tables gradually filled up over the next hour, but it was by no means full... maybe people don't fancy roast for Saturday lunch. Anyway, I ordered the whole roast grouse and my friend ordered the jugged hare. I enjoyed the grouse but was surprised that the meat was fairly rare, and was also not a big fan of the hairy feet left on the bird. As for the hare, I had a bite and the consistency was of stewed beef casserole but the meat has a very particular taste to it... I doubt I could eat a whole plate of it, but it is interesting and worth trying. All in all, I think the restaurant provides a very different take on pub food aside from the usual fish & chips, etc., and I feel like if you do a dish like jugged hare well, that probably earns you some serious points in the dining award world. Also to note, the menu is not cheap, with most items in the 25-30 pound area, on par with a high end restaurant but definitely not anything like your average pub!

jwfBBDn3cBwIP4mIou8jyw.text: This was attached to our hotel, Montcalm, and was great. Nice selection of beers and nice atmosphere. While it can get crowded, this was a great place to soak in the London business district post work culture

AKsWoC4ZmFEM4G9_WWSd-w.text: So this is a short review of the pub in this gastropub.  A very traditional and well appointed Victorian pub in this now fashionable bit of London.  They have a great range of beers and there's really nothing bad to say about the place.  It's off the beaten track a bit, but if you have cause to be around the Barbican, this pub is worth a look.  It you're here at lunch time and don't fancy the menu or the prices there's always Whitecross St market to source your weight gain of choice.

il0l6aFQc-6Q7YLQxPv9ww.text: Ate in the restaurant on a Friday night. Great style and food, decent value and friendly service. However, we could hardly hear ourselves because of the unfortunate acoustics and the loud customers near us.

qNvFZIJqxvPhcRdj__dc7A.text: Came here with friends on a recommendation and overall had a lovely time. Food seemed great overall. We were there on Sunday so people mainly had a variety of roasts. I had a mallard, which was a special, and while it's pricey at £28, you do literally get a whole bird. I was a bit disappointed with the game chips, which turned out to basically be salted crisps - I was imagining something a bit heartier. But the meat was pink and delicious. My friends were also very enthusiastic about their mutton, chicken and sausages and mash, and the various roast accompaniments (carrots, cauliflower cheese, roast potatoes, etc). The pecan and treacle tart was a tad disappointing because I'd envisaged something more like a pecan pie, but it was nice enough. Friends enjoyed all their desserts, which I think were sticky toffee pudding and apple crumble. Overall what confirmed it as a 4* spot to eat was how everybody was discussing what they would have next time, which is a good sign!The vibe inside is great and it does feel more high end than just a gastropub, which is fortunate considering the higher prices. Service started off great, with the right amount of attention, and we always had full water glasses. However, there were some long gaps (waiting to get dessert menus, waiting for the bill), which weren't a problem on a lazy Sunday afternoon but would have been irritating in different circumstances. We also had a waiter who didn't know what lime and soda was and brought us lemonade, which was a little odd in a pub, but a more senior guy remedied the situation quickly and pleasantly.

ZcupA6QEeCLDaTw2AmYeLA.text: British gastropub with game meat and fine wine available by glass or bottle including 1999 Valduero Gran Reserva at £1750 bottle, elegant red silky smooth, aroma from 6 oaks and full finish. Braised Devonshire kid is melt-in-mouth flavorful. Suckling pig is deliciously tender and fatty, in European (not american) size portions.

photos.caption: Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom

9uKjbszU9FSYfYHrQuhyDA.text: I expected this gastro pub to be overcrowded and pricey. From walking in the door to exiting I was impressed. No crowds, good food and easy too talk with friend. I bought a round first which included a glass of wine. The pour was one of the most generous I have seen worldwide with him finishing off the rest of the bottle. As we had our drinks we perused the restaurant menu which screamed UK countryside to me with rabbit, pigeon and pork as just some of the delicious options. My partner and I shared the leg of a suckling pig they had.  All I can say is it was top notch! The only thing that annoyed me about this place and why it didn't get 5 stars was the assumed 12% service charge.

photos.caption: Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. Suckling pig

eQmuNx7QP4JyGh9mYSOI0Q.text: Really quintessential brasserie with very nice natural lighting.The starters were delicious and well-portioned. So much so that after ordering four between the three of us, we were quite satisfied without mains. Delicious terrine, fantastic crab meat salad, the wild bore pie was delightful. I wish we'd had room for mains!Protip 1 - don't ask the staff for recommendations. Their finger will go right to the most expensive option available. Protip 2 - They sell these rare black gull eggs for £7.50 each. Avoid. It's a raw egg, with salt, pepper and mayonnaise on the side. Tastes like any other egg, though apparently only five families in the world can harvest them. But stories and rarity don't impart flavor!

v-qQbfzf6fhRgayUE-LVZw.text: Ducked in for a quick coffee with a friend here last week.  I was traveling and they stored my luggage for me while we sat down for a bite.  I was eyeing the lovely buffet, but at 22 pounds, I wasn't persuaded.There wasn't anything on the menu I wanted either.  "Would it be a huge bother," I asked, "to simply have two poached eggs and bacon?"  After consulting with the kitchen, she said that would be fine and charged me 5 pounds for two PERFECTLY poached eggs and about 8 rashers of bacon.  AMAZING.Thanks guys.  Will return if I'm in the neighborhood for all that amazing game you serve up.

lPyGaDD8Oj9oyC9KfIxNgA.text: A Great place to eat and very central from Moorgate and Barbican (located nearer to the Barbican Centre) lively atmosphere, very welcoming staff, this place is full of photos on the wall of animals and stuffed animals in display cases especially Hares! (see my pictures) food was to die for, I had the Rump Steak, with King Scallops for starters and Apricot crumble with Honey Ice Cream for dessert, so if you are in the area and need a place to eat then this is the place! I'm definitely going back again and very reasonably priced for central London.

photos.caption: Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. June 2015
Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. June 2015
Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. June 2015

CmJ-v0peh-dFOKyGcCgfWA.text: This is an absolutely classic British pub near the Barbican. I just went in for drinks after work and enjoyed myself. The bar is a bit busy, it's a bit loud, but that's your normal pub. They have their own craft brewed beer which you can ask for, and it's at a good price for a London pub. Definitely recommend stopping in if you're in the area.

Kdx6V7g6mVTCbi3cxbauCQ.text: I just went here for a couple of drinks with friends after work and thought it was quite nice, stylish place! Sooooooooo many dead animals on the walls though. If you're a fan of taxidermy this is the bar for you. I had a glass of red (after being ID'ed for the third time this week?!) surrounded by about 10 stuffed hares heads, which was a bit sad =[ I didn't have any snacks, but the chunky chips smelled great!! Was very tempted to snaffle one from the table behind us =]

95xfawiauU3itqvEDxOeOQ.text: Came on a sunday night at 10:03. Sign says they are open til 10:30. Waitress turned me away and said they were closed. Would've been fine if she wasn't rude about it. But she was! What a jerk. Food looks fine though.

PhyGAeC7RV4MrokH8fKckw.text: One of the best Gastropubs i have been too, There Sunday Roast Dinners are the best i have had! Yes at the pricey side at around £18 a head but very good. Wine is superb and they have a vast array to choose from, the whole restaurant looked awesome, we finished with a beer by the bar in this electric London City Pub, It is also very close to the Barbican.

8xjgr37XwMBcj2R7jSZBEA.text: Go for the cocktails, stay for the food.  Loved the mutton Sunday roast with mint jelly.

photos.caption: Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. Sunday Roast
Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. Hares!

MXnOj8fulrANN_OTjPorCQ.text: The Jugged Hare is a great higher-end gastro-pub near the Barbican Centre. Highly recommended for a quick pint or even better if you stay for dinner.The rotisserie menu is the way to go. I agree wholeheartedly with Zoe K that the 1/2 chicken was juicy and flavourful. My friends all seemed to enjoy their roast of aged meats....the side of sprouting brocoli with almond butter looked amazing. Strangely enough the special of the day was "squirrel pie" which sadly none of us tried. There is a long list of grilled meats and fishes, so plenty of choice or even the fussy of carnivores.The atmosphere definitely draws a wealthier well put together clientele, though the excessive taxidermy on display by the bar is rather bizarre. What's the story behind the stuffed ferret?!?

photos.caption: Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom

ZhgFSle7IjYyiR7QcpjXyQ.text: After searching online for a Sunday roast not far from my hotel I came across the Jugged Hare. On my way out of the hotel I asked the concierge where he would suggest for a Sunday roast and without any hesitation he said the Jugged Hare is where he would go.  The atmosphere was nice, I wish the bar stools were a little more comfortable to have a meal on.  I had their Sunday special of 45day aged rump roast with a yorkshire pudding, roasted carrots, a creamed cauliflower which was out of this world, and some roasted potatoes. My only problems with the meal were the carrots had horseradish on them which I was not expecting since i'm not a fan of the flavor they were however still good once dipped in the gravy or the cream sauce from the cauliflower.  The roast potatoes were lacking flavor but were again saved by the gravy and cream sauce.

5dBvGkTg9C4RYNgKFNhpBg.text: I was expecting a lot from their Sunday roast. Food was okay, not amazing. Service was kind of lacking. But overall worth a try since the space is pretty cool

GNFtednN86zBM9a2tQofUA.text: My favorite part about this great gastropub might seem trivial, but it's so useful and such a nice small touch to the dining experience. There's a small little section on the top-right hand side of the menu that tells you what type of food is in season. How nice of them, and pretty clever.From the start, I was impressed with the range of the menu and there seemed to see so many delicious options to choose from. Unfortunately, the in-season salmon was out for the day, so I opted for the Atlantic Cod instead as my main. It was light and flaky and flavourful, served on a bed of peas. My friend had the mutton bomb, which was fantastic - the meat was juicy and tender and the pastry was flaky and buttery. For sides, we had the steak chips and the turnips, all good choices.I particularly liked that they had a "pairing" wine lists for certain mains on their menu. Who needs a sommlier when that's done for you already?All in all, a great place.

photos.caption: Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. Atlantic Cod

G6ewukEBvuJIrwcfrRhCBw.text: Nice pub in central London. Really good selection of craft beer. Prices are reasonable for a city pub too. I only tried the chips so can't really comment on the food, they were nice chunky chips though! Unusual decor - worth a visit.

jioTiGCf26eV2yLpyuboyw.text: The food and wine were stunning, it is a very popular place so book early! One thing that made me not wanting to come back there again is beheaded hare downstairs exhibited with other slaughtered animals. I thought this was ott, eating them is bad enough... Sorry

zpK3-a7ubQA954qqcdaWyw.text: This is the best place in London for a Sunday dinner. The half chicken and the roast are both unbelievably good. And they come with a ton of roasted potates and carrots. The atmosphere was also perfect. Quite enough to chat and busy enough to feel cozy. I would go here every Sunday night if I lived here.

YG1xZq7OE16LBSYpviPA6A.text: Items ordered:Nyetimber Classic Cuvee 2004, West Sussex EnglandIrish Soda Bread with ButterWhipped Pig with Toast, Salt Cod Brandade CakesCloanakilty Irish Black Pudding Croquettes with Guinness SauceWild Boar Head Croquettes with Apple CaramelRoast Leg of Herdwick Mutton, Mint Jelly, Yorkshire Pudding, Duck Fat Roasted Potatoes, Carrots and Cabbage, Cauliflower au GratinStrawberry PavlovaWith my fine dining itinerary set months in advance it was only after substantial research that my agenda for more traditional British fare was elucidated and knowing full well that a traditional Sunday Roast, preferably with mutton, was something I wanted to experience it was only after screening nearly two dozen spots that I decided on The Jugged Hare - my research well rewarded in a decadent meal amongst the most memorable of the trip.  Owned and operated by a group known as ETM and strikingly similar to several hundred local pubs on its façade my arrival at The Jugged Hare followed a touristy trek of the surrounding area and having worked up an appetite on foot my arrival was met with all smiles as a polite hostess led me to a table in direct view of the kitchen where heavy woods and taxidermy decorated the space on all sides.  Every bit English in its offerings though admittedly a bit 'themed' in its feel it was with greedy eyes that I took in a menu offering no less than twenty things I'd like to try and after discussing portions with my server a six-part order was placed, though sides and accoutrements would push plates north of ten.  Declining beer and instead beginning in brisk British bubbles that stood up nicely to starters it was in a duo of creamy cod fritters and cured pork fat studded with sausage that my meal began and with kitchen clearly looking on at a man they'd presumed to have over-ordered it was not long before I was treated to round two - a half-dozen crispy croquettes stuffed with richly spiced meats finding a sweet balance in a duo of sauces.  At this point going strong as the room began to fill and I stood to browse the décor it was perhaps thirty minutes later that my main course arrived and thankful for the break as I delved into the saporous lamb flanked by sides I could not help but smile, the potatoes and gratin amongst the best I've had in some time and the Yorkshire Pudding something sorely lacking throughout the United States.  Admittedly well sated at this point it was to the lightness of meringue that I turned for dessert and somewhere between a proper pavlova and a semi-constructed Eton Mess the concoction proved peerless; a blend of chilled cream and fresh strawberries juxtaposing bits of sugary crunch to tantalize the palate without making much impact on an already full stomach.

photos.caption: Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. Cloanakilty Irish Black Pudding Croquettes with Guinness Sauce, Wild Boar Head Croquettes with Apple Caramel
Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. Cloanakilty Irish Black Pudding Croquettes with Guinness Sauce, Wild Boar Head Croquettes with Apple Caramel
Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. Cloanakilty Irish Black Pudding Croquettes with Guinness Sauce, Wild Boar Head Croquettes with Apple Caramel

m8dzrcwBhhF3lu9P2kCegg.text: We needed a place to eat near the Barbican, and this gastropub was luckily right around the corner. Since we came around 6 on a Friday night, we were immediately seated. If you're a PETA advocate, you probably want to give Jugged Hare a miss since taxidermy is the prime source of decor.We ordered the steak with truffle mash and cauliflower puree (not sure the price because we subbed in a different cut of steak since the one listed was sold out) and the roast chicken (£17.50).  The steak was cooked a bit too rare, but the sauce and mash were great accompaniments.  Chicken was a a little dry but still nice with crispy skin.  Peach crumble (£6) contained huge chunks of peach, and went well with the contrast of ginger ice cream.

homB9tnI7Xqb1RnKjikxvw.text: Stopped in after an exhibit at the Barbican to treat us to a nice dinner and drinks. The pub has a hunting cabin feel with taxidermy animals all over the place. There was even a cooked pigs head at the place where they serve up the food, which was kinda gross, but I guess they use all parts of the animal?I ordered the pheasant on the menu of the day and we split a bottle of red for the table. The wine was nice and smooth and went well with dinner. The pheasant came out with the thigh and leg, and the foot still attached. It was a bit off putting, but the pheasant itself was nice. The gravy provided helped to moisten up the bird a bit and give more flavor. On the side were chips (crisps really) and asparagus. Overall the food was nice and the wine was lovely. The ambiance fit with the menu. The place is on the pricier side, but if you're looking for a place with an English hunting menu.. this is the place to come!

hf0dTJFT_AENVgjgyLz9NQ.text: Upscale british pub food is an apt description for this place. I was staying nearby and wanted to grab a nice dinner with local fare and our concierge recommended this pub.  Word of warning about the decor - stuffed birds, and stuffed fox / deer / bunnies is the decor of choice.  Every nook is filled with their black eyes, staring as you chow down on venison and other game meat. The menu is certainly impressive, with british delicacies like wellington, meat pies, fish, steak, etc.  Some of the descriptions were incredibly detailed like this is a female dairy cow, 2 years into retirement.  Not sure that was the most appetizing description of "flank steak", and did turn me off of ordering the beef.  I ordered the restaurant's namesake dish - a jugged hare, which came with a side of cabbage with bacon bits, and mashed potatoes.  The hare is actually served in a JUG, like the kind you would pour lemonade from on a hot, humid summer day.   I also ordered a side of bone marrow sauce - which happened to be the saving grace of my meal.  The hare was incredibly dry and tasted almost like a pulled chicken, the meat was completely shredded and mixed in with a very watery sauce.  Mash was typical mash, and the cabbage needed some more time on the stove, crunchy in a toothsome way.  The food overall was pretty bland and boring, in desperate need of salt and pepper to impart any flavor.

d0ybq6rxbQoSDHG7tjqE_A.text: Loud happening place on a Thursday night. Great food and vibe but the taxidermy  was a little bit of a turn off.

zMRJoCEUX_6piXLeK5Gxkw.text: Holy amazingness. Came in here late one night with a party of eight and basically closed the place down. Had an incredible meal - some burgers, some mussels and at the end a bunch of sticky toffee puddings.Chilled tomato soup was not a winner, but the poached whole artichoke was absolutely amazing. Had the potted Hampshire Trout which was also delicious. Also tried the haggis scotch egg and crispy pigs ears which were exactly as expected. So yummy.Amazing service, great hand-pulled ale selection and a perfect London-y ambience.Could've come back here 10 times during our visit. So good.

1WOjWcoav8QqkXN7F2gW0g.text: Delicious and soulful. Whetted the palate with glasses of Bordeaux and kicked it off with sizzling scallops and white onion soup. I followed w the jugged rabbit and my partner, the wild boar trotter hot pot. They were aromatic, tender and perfectly sauced. If we had anymore room we would have happily ordered dessert but wanted to savor the fullness in our bellies. Atmosphere is on point - I felt like I had entered a menagerie of fowl and small and medium game, but not circus like and v respectful of the offerings. Service was good despite a busy night and well worth the cost. Can't wait to return to try more and more!

ce8vIuTFoRYoxYmdaT95RQ.text: I went for a late lunch and this place still had a great vibe. Meat lovers will be heaven. I went for the 1/2 chicken and it was superb. Large wine menu. Great atmosphere and everything looks very good. You pick your meat and sides, do Mix n Match.

photos.caption: Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. 1/2 chicken, sage dressing, mashed potatoes and gravy...yum!

Vt8b8b14CIJIi2AlOqeHMw.text: Pretty great dinner which I really was not expecting. Definitely not your usual pub fare. We stopped in and didn't expect much really but we left pretty content and pleasantly surprised. Try to make a reservation, we stopped in and was squeezed in by the host. Try the pig jowl starter and the pork t bone.

PVzMtTHXFoeJZ4TURHaBqA.text: This place is a meat-lover's heaven. The game heads hanging on the wall really add to the hunting lodge vibe, and the food is incredible. I went for Sunday roast and was greeted with the most glorious rump roast, with potatoes cooked in duck fat and cheesy cauliflower gratin. The house Ale was spot on too. Make a reservation, though it's off the beaten path, near the Barbican, it is extremely popular and fills up quick at lunch.

photos.caption: Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. Sunday roast was out of this world.

EvTNCOhbB2CM8fenH5sGOQ.text: Probably one of the best Sunday roasts in London. A true gamer's paradise, this gastropub is decorated as traditional brasserie-meets hunter's trophy room. Taxidermy sidles up next to brass finishings and elegant dining areas. I love the expansive paintings depicting the thrill of the hunt - complete with hounds, hares, horses, fanfare and jodhpur-clad round-bellied men. If you're up for dining in this environment, it's only the icing on the cake.The food is WONDERFUL. Duck fat chips, Yorkshire puddings, roast mutton, quail, hare, roast beef, wild boar -- any and every cut of meat, dripping in fat, oven-roasted for hours. We had the Sunday rump roast and liver terrine. The wine selection by the glass was perfectly complementary and the place wasn't too crowded. In all, an excellent selection of fine fare, good drinks and English ambiance.

s8rZE8PaIHhmQUIGGa_fOw.text: Celebrating my first English meal in London at The Jugged Hare felt right. The gastropub is clean with ample wooden decor (also taxidermy everywhere!). Our party sat at one of the barrels and enjoyed the sunlight coming in through the atrium. Great ambiance to spend Sunday afternoon catching up with friends.Beers on tap are cask ale, bitburger, heineken, etc. I've never tried/heard of cask ale before, but my party introduced it as uncarbonated, warm beer. Sounds interesting enough to try it one of these days. My Sunday Roast with beef was really a feast. Although you can get it with chicken or lamb, the beef is aged for 45 days. The horseradish was on the creamier side without enough kick so that I felt the beef to be overwhelmed. However, the steamed vegetables were seasoned well and contrasted well to the cauliflower cheese gratin.

photos.caption: Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. Sunday roast - beef with horseradish

GFYQYPj72pnRNRMMxoyHNA.text: Who knew there was a restaurant stuck over on the side here. The pictures and menu look great. I want to eat here on my next trip. I was hauled in by customers after a day of meetings.The atmosphere excellent. You could drop the bartenders into any American hipster bar and they would look like they belonged. It's too bad things like that get globalized. Anyway the beer selection excellent, The selection of whisky and whiskey was top notch. I didn't try a cocktail, but they looked like they were prepared with fresh ingredients and with skill.

photos.caption: Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. Great vibe at the bar
Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. Great selection of Whisky and Whiskey

8YTOh_Q80riVnYGZGnsLQg.text: Visited with my wife and son for Sunday Roast.  The bar area has a modern pub atmosphere.  There are big windows with a great deal of natural light.   The dining room is open to the kitchen, which we enjoyed.  We started with pork cracklngs and Whitely Goose toast.  The pork cracklings were excellent.  We all agreed the Whitley Goose toast was over the top but that was our own appetizer pairing mistake.The Sunday Roast comes with a nice compliment of vegetables, duck fat potatoes and carrots.  They were fantastic.  The carrots in particular were noteworthy.    For the mains we ordered goat shank, longhorn rump and mutton.  They were all great.  The shank was the best of the three.  The mutton was served with a beautiful mint flecked jelly.We all enjoyed the atmosphere and had a very pleasant Sunday meal.  I would have given an extra star but the waiter was blatantly up-selling from the moment we sat down.  Without being asked he  kept pushing us towards one of the most expensive bottles on the list.  Frankly it was obvious and off-putting.  I wish he was more helpful in our selection of       appetizers as we clearly could have used his assistance in that department.All in all is was a nice meal on a rainy Sunday afternoon.

1PMc4neyzA8xZkiqaKfxSQ.text: If you want a great pub meal in nice and perhaps a bit unusual surroundings (there is stuffed birds, deer and hares around the pub and down the stairs and in the restaurant paintings of hares etc) then I totally recommend this pub. All the staff that work there are very friendly and cheerful.  I sat along the back of the wall so I was able to see the kitchen / pass from where I was sat, loved it.  I enjoyed watching the head chef at the pass especially.  The restaurant serves various food from your traditional homemade pie to Lobster.  For starters me and my husband both had scallops with black pudding, for mains I had cod on a herb risotto, my husband steak with chunky chips (I don't like chips but my The Jugged Hares was amazing and so crispy and hot) and for dessert I had Lemon tart and my husband apricot and apple crumble. Portions was a good size, everything was steaming hot and all the food tasted lovely. I would go back and eat there if I am in the area.   The toilet area is downstairs and I must admit I was surprised by its niceness and how clean the bathroom area was, very well kept.  Love the waterfall taps and the towels that are piled up on the table.  Only one piece of advice I feel is that for pub food the meals are a bit on the expensive side and this is why I only give my review 4 stars but that is not a criticism as I would go back.

photos.caption: Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom

dr0Js7kAFfqJvjsdLn3X8g.text: Have eaten here on many occasions and have always found the food to be of a very good standard. It has an open kitchen where you can sit up and watch the chefs do there thing or alternatively, have a table in a more relaxed seating. The food is seasonal specialising in game along with spit roast meats as well as fish. I have personally tried the namesake dish and it's lovely, hare which is cooked in its own blood. They do an awesome Sunday roast also. There is also a lovely outside seating area across the road where in the summer you can relax in comfortable seating and simply watch the city pass by. The Jugged Hare should definitely be on your list to try.

photos.caption: Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. Bar Area
Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. Jugged Hare Ale

PisClR_ruX3HEBBc9FhHCw.text: This was a really nice restaurant (ambiance, service, bunny-heads etc.) and was listed as one of the best places to go for Sunday lunch on multiple sites.  However, while the food was okay, it certainly didn't live up to the hype.  We had the mutton and the beef for the main and the cheeseboard for dessert.  The food was good but on the bland side.

YoWNwtUC5-K00BEbrGxOfA.text: I can think of nothing better than spending a Sunday afternoon with a group of friends, and a variety of meats!  In which case the Jugged Hare was perfect.As you enter the pub the main wall behind the bar is a glass case of taxidermy.  To the right mounted antelope and rabbit heads.  The main restaurant wall decorated with prints of animals. This bodes well for the meaty game theme.I'd read good things about the Sunday roast, so was keen to give this a go.  Between 6 of us we had the 45 day aged rump roasts, bacon croquettes, boar bombs, rabbits liver on toast, scallops, and a rump steak.  The liver and scallops were from the specials menu.  Each dish was a well prepared, good sized portion.  I get really excited when a restaurant serves cauliflower cheese with their Sunday roasts, and the Jugged Hare serves up a delicious side with theirs.Service was really friendly and accommodating.  The waitress arranged for a kids portion of fish and chips for the one child we had in the group. It turned out to be a lovely grilled piece of cod, triple cooked chips, and a side of veg.  On the way out we were shown the ageing cabinet where meat is hung, which was gross and pretty great all at the same time.All in all a pretty great afternoon of eating.  We will definitely be back for more!

photos.caption: Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. The bar
Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. Bacon croquettes and boar bomb

WBWtzTif6QTtMBklnHWq5g.text: A real treat.  Great for game meats: rabbit/Hare, pheasant, grouse, hake...   Terrific service who will help you with the menu.  Good for those who don't like game, too with fish and chicken.  Great atmosphere.  Doubles as a great meal and a wonderful experience.

lsncJodkcS5NyeiJVK1haQ.text: The name of this place sounds like a pub, and when you walk in, the front part feels like a pub. Except there's a nice restaurant hidden in the back, and they serve a lot of interesting British fare.The menu points out which foods are in season, and there are plenty of seasonal offerings. They specialize in game, but if you're not that adventurous, they do have some normal items.We started with some queen scallops with chorizo and garlic. Hmmmmm so delicious and creamy. We also had a salad, but in the face of all these yummy game meats, I could barely remember what it was.I had the roe deer and port sausage with mashed potatoes, which was a game version of bangers and mash, essentially. The mash and the roast onion was very, very savory, and you could definitely taste a hint of herb in there. The roe deer sausage was interesting but a bit grainy, so it wasn't as good as I had hoped. On the other hand, you could tell it was a freshly made sausage.I really wish I had tried the jugged hare since I never had that dish. I read about it online and got cold feet... (poor rabbit). If you're a traveller craving for British pub food with a flair, this is a good place to go!

photos.caption: Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. Chestnut cheesecake that wasn't so chestnutty
Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom. "Bangers and mash": roe deer sausage and mashed potatoes.

5Iw--oSUJ-Zz5ysnpjNRwA.text: If you are the mood for authentic English, including properly sourced wild game, you would struggle to do better.   The service and atmosphere are very good and the food is extremely well considered.  They clearly think about what they are doing and have a distinct philosophy of food.   Handy after an evening at the Barbican  Centre as well!

photos.caption: Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Jugged Hare - London, United Kingdom

n7r65-BJ1MZPimHYegfZ5g.text: First off, this review must be taken in the context of a review for city drinks. I didn't eat at the place, but the food looks amazing. This was an upscale but neighborhood feeling bar with a lively but not to crowded atmosphere on Thursday night (probably more crowded at the end of dry Jan). Great selection of beer on tap, wine (pricy) and good gin behind the bar. Their jugged hair ale was tasty as well as the ipa on tap. Also had an expertly made gin and tonic with ginger instead of lime made with opirh gin. My one complaint is that they automatically poured double which made the drink pricy. Would have loved to try the wild boar scotch egg but the kitchen was closed. Also had olives behind the bar. The eating menu looked game centric but also expensive. Would come back to eat. What's best is that this place is on my walk home from the city. For good drinks and nibbles, this is a gem.
